answers.text: Paul Ehrlich and chemist Alfred Bertheim

qas.question: What was the first effective treatment for Syphilis?
What complications are associated with Syphilis?

answers.text: severe skin ulceration, neurological damage, and death

qas.question: Where is the Institute of Experimental Therapy located?
What was the name of the first synthetic bacterial drug?
Bacterial infections could be treated with medicines containing what kind of dye?
Arsphenamine became the first treatment for what previously incurable disease?
In what year was arsphenamine discovered?
What was the commercial name of arsphenamine?

plausible_answers.text: Paul Ehrlich and chemist Alfred Bertheim

qas.question: What was the first effective treatment for Bertheim?
What complications are associated with Bertheim?
Where is the Institute of Bertheim located?

context: In <a8_0>1911<a8_0/> <a5_0>arsphenamine<a5_0/>, the first synthetic anti-infective drug, was developed by <a0_0><b10_0>Paul Ehrlich and chemist Alfred Bertheim<b10_0/><a0_0/> of the <a3_0><b13_0>Institute of Experimental Therapy<b13_0/><a3_0/> in <a4_0><b14_0>Berlin<b14_0/><a4_0/>. The drug was given the commercial name <a9_0>Salvarsan<a9_0/>. Ehrlich, noting both the general toxicity of arsenic and the selective absorption of certain dyes by bacteria, hypothesized that an <a6_0>arsenic<a6_0/>-containing dye with similar selective absorption properties could be used to treat bacterial infections. <b11_0>Arsphenamine<b11_0/> was prepared as part of a campaign to synthesize a series of such compounds, and found to exhibit partially selective toxicity. <a1_0>Arsphenamine<a1_0/> proved to be the first effective treatment for <a7_0>syphilis<a7_0/>, a disease which prior to that time was incurable and led inexorably to <a2_0><b12_0>severe skin ulceration, neurological damage<b12_0/>, and death<a2_0/>.[citation needed]
